job_title: Undergraduate Research Associate in Lakeland, FL
pros: You can usually do your own hours depending on who you work for. Research can sometimes end up with a paper, so if you want recognition in academia its a good experience.
cons: The pay is only 10/hr which isn't much to live off of when you are also limited to 20hrs per week.

job_title: Student Research Assistant in Lakeland, FL
pros: The small number of students at FLPoly allows for unique opportunities that other universities cannot provide. I was able to work as a student research assistant as a Freshman, which is something Freshmen at other universities rarely get the privilege of doing.
cons: The university is young and still growing, so there is a limited amount of staff and equipment available to student researchers.

job_title: Administrative Assistant II in Lakeland, FL
pros: No comments. Great job in general
cons: Too much at the same time

pros: You're probably reading these reviews because you are considering working here. Don't--it's really that simple. There's huge turnover, lots of politics and drama, and rude and arrogant department chairs. They are perpetually short staffed because they do not treat people well and egos count more than results.
cons: My suggestion is to pass on this one. You'll experience uncertainty from one semester to the next, one year to the next. It's just a matter of time before this school is absorbed into another state university for proper oversight.

pros: Fast pace environment, Interdisciplinary work and communication.
cons: There were no cons for me. Great experience.

review_title: Excellent way to get to know people
pros: Working as an admissions associate was very fun! You get to know all of the admissions and financial aid staff as well as just getting to know other administrative people and school employees. It is not overly demanding and many times even fun to do some of the tasks that are required.
cons: Sometimes you do need to do more meaningless tasks such as calling incoming students all afternoon and becoming very used to leaving the same voicemail message.

pros: Good people, nice environment, growing culture
cons: Because it is new, there are some growing pains

review_title: “University” is not an appropriate title for this institution...
pros:
The administration and board of trustees like employees with no ethics and who are at least slightly incompetent. If you can’t get a job at another “university” because of these attributes you will fit in great here!

Another bonus is the 27 point culture program that the “university” paid $40k in state dollars for. If you are into cult like mentality, you will really enjoy this. They even had mandatory quizzes the first 27 weeks to drill it into employees heads!

If you are interested in being part of an organization that takes state money to pay big salaries and pay for an expensive garden, but nickel and dime the education efforts, this is your kind of place! Millennials need to quit “complaining “ about getting a good education!
cons:
All of the positive employees complaining about all the other employees (negative people) who like ethics, doing the right thing, and students. They need to quit harassing and bullying everyone else who hasn’t joined the cult!

If you don’t like discrimination and harassment, this may not be your cup of tea.  Misogyny is pretty rampant (you better smile!). Offensive rhetoric from the people on top is a M-F affair.

If you are competent and live by the code of “doing the right thing”... run! You will be quickly labeled “negative” and wonder how you ended up in a job that gaslights you on the daily.

review_title: Love my position and Florida Poly
pros:
Cabinet working hard to improve workplace culture
Provost, faculty, and staff working hard to provide a rigorous curriculum
Vice Provost of Academic Success works hard to provide wonderful internship opportunities for our students - providing real world experiences
Great work opportunities for research and student assistants
Pay and benefits are aligned with where they should be
Hours are great - work life balance
Always something to do, don't get bored
Working with the students and being a part of their success
cons: Tired of the negativity.  The reviews that are terrible are probably from those that got fired. You have a small group of complainers that complain loudly.  Get out of the administrations way so they can do their job. If you truly love your job and what you do, you give 100% every day and are committed to student and university success, you don't have anything to worry about.  If you're lazy and get involved in drama, then just look for another job because they'll figure it out eventually.

pros: Florida Poly is a blank slate. Whether you are a faculty member or a staff member, you have the opportunity to create. The professionals on the ground are welcoming and friendly. The students are my favorite part of working at Poly. They are eager to get involved in projects and research.
cons: The politics and the way decisions are made without taking best practices into consideration. There is no real strategic vision or specific goals for where the colleges and the departments are headed. The environment is very unstructured without accountability from top to bottom.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Winter Haven, FL
pros:
Lots of staff who try really hard to do their very best.
Higher pay than local opportunities.
Potential big future for university, with major management changes.
cons:
No equity amongst similarly-positioned staff.
No substantive training opportunities
Few opportunities for advancement.
Too many unqualified individuals hired.
Top heavy; not enough lower level support
